awd_titl_txt: TWC: Small: Techniques and Tools for General-Purpose Secure Computing and Outsourcing
awd_abstract_narration:
The rapid advancement of techniques for secure computation on protected data offers a major incentive for development of tools for general-purpose secure computation that protects data privacy, as opposed to computation of specialized tasks. The recent emergence of cloud computing and the need to protect privacy of sensitive data used in outsourced computation serves as another major motivation for this work. With this in mind, this project targets at developing a compiler suitable for privacy-preserving execution of any functionality specified by a user program. Our compiler transforms a program written in an extension of the C programming language, where data to be protected are marked as private, into its secure distributed implementation in C, which can be consecutively compiled into a binary executable by a native compiler. The goal of the project is to preserve all features of the programming language and enable efficient implementation of user programs using a number of optimization techniques. The secure distributed computation is implemented using secure multi-party techniques on secret-shared data and is suitable for secure collaborative computation and secure computation outsourcing.

These techniques will allow for more secure cloud computing, even in the presence of attackers.  Other broader impacts include outreach to female middle school girls to increase interest in computer science, a summer school program for graduate students on secure computation in the cloud, and involving students from a nearby predominantly African-American university in the research program.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to provide support and the necessary tools for general-purpose secure multi-party computation and outsourcing. Secure computation allows for private data that belongs to different organizations to be used in joint computation while guaranteeing that no unintended information about the data is revealed as a result of the computation. Similarly, secure outsourcing refers to one's ability to delegate computation on private data to one or more not fully trusted cloud servers without revealing any information about the private data to the servers. The data is protected from the parties carrying out the computation via cryptographic techniques and only computation output is made available to the agreed-upon participants. While these techniques experienced significant performance improvement during recent years, optimized constructions were available only for a rather narrow domain of integer arithmetic and a limited number of other operations. As we try to make these techniques readily accessible to wider communities such as software developers without extensive cryptographic training, there was a need for efficient implementations of general-purpose programming language constructs in the secure computation framework. This includes supporting operations on private data of standard data types and data-oblivious, i.e., data-independent, data structures and algorithms where the program execution trace and memory locations that a program accesses are guaranteed to not reveal any information about the private data.

Towards this goal, this project developed efficient constructions for working with standard data types in the secure computation framework. The project outcomes also include data-oblivious algorithms for fundamental graph problems such as the shortest path, minimum spanning tree, maximum flow, and maximum matching size in bipartite graphs. Most importantly, the project developed a compiler, called PICCO, for transforming a user program written in C, which is intended to work with private data, into the corresponding secure distributed implementation. The compiler supports all C features including pointers to private data, dynamic memory allocation, etc., which allows one to build any desired data structure using private data. All results have been disseminated to the research community. 

The project has societal benefits such as support for private, proprietary, classified, or otherwise sensitive data to be used in any type of computation without compromising its privacy and the ability to automatically generate programs for doing so. As an additional benefit to the society, the privacy-friendly techniques and tools produced as a result of this research will provide a more realistic possibility for collaborative computation over private or sensitive data. The techniques are useful even when the computational servers are trusted and protect private data in the case of computer break-ins, malware infections, and insider threats.

The project provided human resource development and trained both undergraduate and graduate students. For example, it funded PhD studies of three students who acquired a variety of necessary skills ranging from rigorous cryptographic design, to algorithms, to system implementations. It also funded a summer school for graduate students and post-doctoral scholars who learned about the newest developments in secure and data-oblivious computation and outsourcing from world experts in the field.
